div.p: Worthy and gracious, dear sir. I have received your letter well, understood all its contents, and satisfied the messenger. I perceive in this your diligence and faithful promotion, for which I thank you most highly and will thus follow your advice, as well as that of Mr. Bernhard, the honorable man, and follow his good counsel and opinion.
The leaders in Basel offer to uphold their freedom and to act well on my behalf.
Also, the king's envoys, to whom I am now writing, are to moderate my case with the five places.
And when I can now be accompanied to..., I hope my case will turn out well.
If then I am to be treated so inhumanely, as I do not expect, then He who created heaven and earth will help me.

I was highly sought after, but not immediately... it is meant, they want to see how soft other people are, how to deal with them, and when I am expelled, then the freedoms of the Confederates will first be disputed, etc.

I will also make my defense in writing and can endure that it be sent to the emperor, and I will also solicit that those from Basel write about me and say whether I conduct myself well or poorly. I also do not intend to act violently against the Confederation and have not done so.

My king has now been reminded by me several times to renew the confederation with the Confederates; why he delays, we do not know. But regarding England, he should soon be approached with good reasons, etc., diligently.
Herewith commended to God's grace. I ask that the other letters be assigned to their place.
Your very willing S[ebastian] Schertlin subscribes.
To the worthy and well-learned Master Heinrich Bullinger, pastor in ZÃ¼rich, my gracious lord and trusted friend.
